Title: A Systematic Survey of Prompt Engineering on Vision-Language Foundation Models
Authors: Jindong Gu, Zhen Han, Shuo Chen, Ahmad Beirami, Bailan He, Gengyuan Zhang, Ruotong Liao, Yao Qin, Volker Tresp, Philip Torr
Summary: Prompt engineering is a technique that involves augmenting a large pre-trained model with task-specific hints, known as prompts, to adapt the model to new tasks. Prompts can be created manually as natural language instructions or generated automatically as either natural language instructions or vector representations. Prompt engineering enables the ability to perform predictions based solely on prompts without updating model parameters, and the easier application of large pre-trained models in real-world tasks. In past years, Prompt engineering has been well-studied in natural language processing. Recently, it has also been intensively studied in vision-language modeling. However, there is currently a lack of a systematic overview of prompt engineering on pre-trained vision-language models. This paper aims to provide a comprehensive survey of cutting-edge research in prompt engineering on three types of vision-language models: multimodal-to-text generation models (e.g. Flamingo), image-text matching models (e.g. CLIP), and text-to-image generation models (e.g. Stable Diffusion). For each type of model, a brief model summary, prompting methods, prompting-based applications, and the corresponding responsibility and integrity issues are summarized and discussed. Furthermore, the commonalities and differences between prompting on vision-language models, language models, and vision models are also discussed. The challenges, future directions, and research opportunities are summarized to foster future research on this topic.

main_contribution.headline: Comprehensive Survey of Prompt Engineering in Vision-Language Models
main_contribution.description: This paper provides a systematic overview of prompt engineering in vision-language models, a topic that has not been extensively covered in the literature. The authors categorize the models into three types: multimodal-to-text generation models, image-text matching models, and text-to-image generation models. For each type, they provide a brief summary, discuss prompting methods, applications, and associated responsibility and integrity issues. The paper also compares prompting in vision-language models with language models and vision models, highlighting their commonalities and differences.

takeaways.headline: Prompt Engineering: A Versatile Tool for Vision-Language Models
takeaways.description: The paper's comprehensive survey of prompt engineering in vision-language models provides valuable insights for LLM practitioners. It highlights the versatility of prompt engineering, which can be used to adapt large pre-trained models to new tasks without updating model parameters. This makes it easier to apply these models in real-world tasks. The paper also discusses the potential challenges, future directions, and research opportunities in this field, providing a roadmap for future research and development.
takeaways.example: For instance, an LLM practitioner could use the insights from this paper to apply prompt engineering to a vision-language model like CLIP. By providing task-specific prompts, the model could be adapted to a new task, such as image captioning or object detection, without the need for extensive retraining.

novelty_analysis: The paper provides a systematic survey of prompt engineering in vision-language models, a topic that has not been extensively covered in the literature. While it does not introduce a new algorithm or technique, it provides a comprehensive overview of existing methods and their applications, making it a valuable resource for researchers and practitioners in the field.
technical_analysis: The paper is somewhat technical as it requires a basic understanding of large pre-trained models and prompt engineering. However, it does not delve into complex mathematical theories or algorithms, making it accessible to a wide range of readers.
enjoyable_analysis: The paper is well-structured and provides a comprehensive overview of prompt engineering in vision-language models. It is informative and provides practical insights, making it an enjoyable read for those interested in this field.
